thread.section_title: Financial Review - Business, Finance and Investment News | afr.com
thread.title: Star Wars' marketing force awakens
thread.title_full: Star Wars' marketing force awakens | afr.com

author: Catie Low and Primrose Riordan
title: Star Wars' marketing force awakens
text:
Australians are among the world's most passionate Star Wars fans. Disney by Catie Low and Primrose Riordan Australian Star Wars fans were the first in the world to get a look at the new Star Wars: Episode VII – The Force Awakens toys on Thursday as Disney kicked off its global marketing campaign for merchandise Down Under.
Select Toys "R" Us and Target stores staged special midnight openings last night to give Australian Star Wars tragics, young and old, their first taste of the new gear.
In addition to the iconic lightsabers, The Force Awakens range includes women's and girls' apparel for the first time, as well as stationery, books and Lego.
Walt Disney Company Australia and New Zealand managing director Catherine Powell is hoping Star Wars will break the record books, and retailers are predicting it will be bigger than Frozen .
And it just might be, with rolling product launches scheduled right up until the first screening of The Force Awakens on December 17, just eight days out from Christmas.
" Star Wars is a global phenomenon and there are incredibly dedicated, passionate fans in Australia," Ms Powell said.
Aussie fans in hyperdrive Chris Brennan is director of Star Walking Inc, the longest-running Star Wars fan club in the world, and he got into costume to help out with the launch.
 Mr Brennan said Australian Star Wars fans were among the most passionate in the world.
He said it was disappointing that a few retailers had "broken the shelf date" for the product, but there was still a lot of excitement about the range.
"There's even a new Millennium Falcon ship being marketed by Hot Toys, but it costs $230,000, so that will only be bought by a few collectors," Mr Brennan said.
Toymaker Hasbro has developed about 90 different products for the Episode VII juggernaut and marketing manager Ben Padfield​ said the long heritage of Star Wars made it "huge property" in toy world.
"It's got every potential to be as big, if not bigger, than Frozen ," Mr Padfield said. "Two thousand and sixteen will be a really big year for Star Wars; people will see the movie in January and February and Star Wars toys will sell every day."
Disney unleashed a rolling, 18-hour launch on Thursday with exclusive "unboxing" events running in cities from Sydney to Seoul to its grand finale in San Francisco.
Unboxing is an online phenomenon where people tune in to websites like Evantube to see toys unpacked and assembled.
Retailers counting on star power Retailers will be hoping Star Wars mania can reignite retail sales, which fell in July for the first time in 14 months, marking a weak start for the economy to the third quarter.
Sales dropped 0.1 per cent from June, when they rose 0.6 per cent, missing economist forecast for a 0.4 increase, Australian Bureau of Statistics figures showed on Thursday.
Household goods retailing led the decline with an outsized 1.9 per cent fall, after a sizeable 2.4 per cent increase the month before.
The rapid deterioration suggests consumers might have brought forward spending because of the government's $20,000 instant asset tax write-off for small businesses.
In the May budget, Prime Minister Tony Abbott coined the term "Tony's tradies" to describe the big winners, handing small businesses the ability to claim an unlimited number of tax deductions for buying cars and machinery valued at less than $20,000 each.
In July, however, electrical and electronic goods retailing fell by 3.3 per cent, and hardware, building and garden supplies retailing dropped by 1.4 per cent.
